Of the Hebrew scriptures. Right. The Old Testament.
Yes. And then even included copies of the Greek translations of the Old Testament.

Absolutely.
And led to a greater recognition of the Septuagint. So just very prominent discovery that had a lot

That's exactly right. We jumped back a thousand years from the earliest copies that we had. And

Right.
It's been changed over time. Because now we could compare, because we had a copy from

Yeah. I mean, from an archaeological or textual perspective,

Right.

Yeah. What else are you going to do?
Aren't you going to talk about your favorite one when you're there, when you're taking a tour?

That&#8217;s an example of archeology not supporting the claims of your religious book. What&#8217;s fun about the Bible is over and over again, the more we discover, the more it just reinforces, the Bible&#8217;s claims and the historicity of it.</p>
<p>And even when people have claimed like, ah, that probably couldn&#8217;t have happened, it&#8217;s just a matter of time than archeology ends up, you know, helping it out.</p>
<p><strong>Chris Legg:</strong> And it was it&#8217;s significant because in that case, Smith didn&#8217;t know, obviously didn&#8217;t know how to translate. And most people could not have translated it.</p>
<p>There were very few people in the world alive who could translate it. And then when the understanding on how to translate it was finally brought to it. <p>That&#8217;s a bad sign that it would quite literally be like, as someone discovered a new test that the new test, one of the new Testament books. In Greek and no one spoke Greek and someone said, this is what it all says. And then someone uncovers how to, how to translate the Greek.</p>
